Fox Island Lighthouse Association Records, 1875-2012

Finding aid created by

did.abstract: The Fox Island Lighthouse Association is a non-profit organization founded to preserve the South Fox Island light station in northern Lake Michigan. The collection contains both paper and digital records, and consists of materials created or collected by the association as part of their efforts to preserve the light station.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by the Association (donor no. 10894) in 2013.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Fox Island Lighthouse Association records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Fox Island Lighthouse Association (FILA) is a Traverse City, Michigan, non-profit organization (501(c)(3)) founded in 2004 by Sandy Bradshaw, John McKinney and Hans Joerg Rothenberger. Their goal was to rekindle the efforts of former groups for rescuing the South Fox Island light station, which had been abandoned in 1959 and has been threatened by gradual decay ever since. South Fox Island is in northern Lake Michigan, about 25 miles north of Leland, Michigan.

The South Fox Island Light Station was active for 101 years, from 1867 to 1968. The first lighthouse was a square light tower attached with an attached keeper's dwelling. In the 1890s, a separate dwelling space for assistant lighthouse keepers was built as well as a fog signal building and other structures. A new, brick assistant keepers' dwelling was built in 1910. In 1934, a new light tower, a skeletal tower taken from Sapelo Island, Georgia, was installed. The light station became automated in 1958 and the last light keeper left the island. The light station was decommissioned in 1968 due to improvements in ships' onboard navigation equipment.

In 1971 the U.S. Department of the Interior transferred 115 acres of land on the southern tip of South Fox Island (excepting the light station buildings and grounds) to the State of Michigan Department of Natural Resources for public use. In 1980, the light station buildings and grounds were also deeded to the State of Michigan.

Until the establishment of the Fox Island Lighthouse Association, few efforts had been made toward the upkeep of the property. One exception was work done in summer 1984 by Michigan Youth Corps members under direction from the Traverse Bay Area Intermediate School District Youth Employment Services. In 2002, the Fox Island Education Association (FIEA) was founded but later disbanded. Two years later, the South Fox Island Lighthouse Restoration Project (SFILRP) was founded by two former FIEA members, Sandy Bradshaw and John McKinney, along with Hans Joerg Rothenberger. SFILRP was renamed Fox Island Lighthouse Association (FILA) in 2005. It gained non-profit status in 2006 and work began on the island later that year. Since then, FILA volunteers have made significant progress in improving the condition of the light station grounds and buildings. A Historic Structure Report, completed in 2011 by U.P. Engineers & Architects and submitted to the State Historical Preservation Office, now guides the restoration and construction work.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains both paper and digital records, and consists of materials created or collected by the Fox Island Lighthouse Association as part of their efforts to preserve the South Fox Island light station. Collected material includes copies of U.S. Lighthouse Service and Coast Guard records from the National Archives, including photographs. The collection also includes the association's newsletters, newspaper articles about the association or the light station, a historic structures report developed for the association by U.P. Engineers & Architects, and a series of oral history interviews of former lighthouse personnel, conducted by association members.

The Fox Island Lighthouse Association records are organized into four series: Organizational Records, Collected Research Materials, Oral Histories, and Visual Materials. All but the Visual Materials series contain both print and digital records, and some documents exist in both formats.

The Organizational Records series (4 folders and 736 MB, 1978-2012) consists of materials documenting or supporting the work of the organization, both on and off the island. This includes copies of FILA newsletters, presentation files, fact sheets about the island and its buildings, and the Historic Structure Report prepared by U.P. Engineers and Architects (which provides a history of the light station in addition to descriptions and recommendations for its buildings and structures) as well as collected news articles about the organization's work and the history of the light station.

did.unittitle: FILA non-profit information: Information sheets, presentation files, newsletters, and other materials
Brochure, restoration notes, and award program 2004-2011
Collage, task list, and captain's log, circa 2009

odd.p: (Collage, task lists and captain's log, circa 2009. Collage shows images of structures on the island. These include images from before and after FILA repair and restoration work was done. The task lists and captain's log file details the goals of the organization regarding work on the island in 2009 and 2010, as well as details of work accomplished in 2009. This includes the amount of material transferred to the island in 2009 and descriptions of various work trips taken between May and October that year.)

did.unittitle: Information sheets on buildings with images, circa 2010

odd.p: (Information sheets on buildings with images, circa 2010. A series of documents about the various buildings of the light station, typically with a collage of several images of each structure. Documents typically include the name and date of the structure; some also include additional information in captions. Buildings include both the original lighthouse and the steel tower, assistant keepers' quarters, boathouse, carpenters' shop/workshop, fog signal building, and oil house. Also includes separate images of the island/its structures and maps of the island.)

did.unittitle: Michigan Waterways Commission Presentation files including photos 2010

odd.p: (Michigan Waterways Commission Presentation files including photos, 2010. Files consist of handouts, presentation slides, and associated images. The presentation showcases the work done by FILA volunteers in repairing and restoring various structures on the island as well as their goals for 2010.)

(Newsletters, Winter 2009, Summer 2010, Fall 2010, Summer 2011, Fall 2011. These publications inform FILA members about the activities of the organization, including outreach efforts and progress on projects both on and off the island. They also include appeals for assistance through in kind and financial donations as well as volunteer hours. Some issues also include information or images related to the history of the light station. Additional issues of newsletters may be found at the Bentley Historical Library in paper format.)

(Notes for FILA spring 2012 newsletter. Very brief draft of an article about the donation of tools for use on the island and a compilation of ideas for what to give the recipient of the Brad Boese Memorial Award.)

did.unittitle: Historic Structure Report for South Fox Island Light Station
Administrative materials, architectural diagrams and plans, images, and feedback 2010-2012

odd.p: (Final report, prepared by U.P. Engineers and Architects, November 30, 2011. The Historic Structure Report consists of six parts: Introduction, including the executive summary, administrative data, and a map of the light station; Developmental History, including the historical background and context and a chronology of development and use; Existing Conditions/Physical Description of the site, light/keeper's dwelling, oilhouse, fog signal building, boathouse, assistant keeper's dwelling, light tower, and carpenter shop; Treatment and Use Recommendations for these structures and others on the island; Cost Estimates; and Appendices, including architectural drawings of the buildings, historic and current photographs, test results, e.g. of lead paint found, other sources, and a bibliography. Additional records relating the Historic Structure Report, including FILA's response to the recommendations and priorities, are held by the Bentley Historical Library in paper form.)

did.unittitle: Collected news articles and other Fox Island information

odd.p: (News articles, brochures, and other documents, 1983 and circa 2010-2011; News articles, fact sheet, and other documents, circa 2009; News article, circa 2010; News article and welcome sheet, circa 2011. Source publications for articles include the Traverse City Record-Eagle, Grand Rapids Press, Great Lakes Boating Federation, and The Beacon. The articles provide information about the organizationâ€™s work and the history of the light station.)

did.unittitle: News articles, brochures, and other documents
News articles, fact sheet, and other documents, circa 2009
News article and welcome sheet, circa 2011

scopecontent.p: The Collected Research Materials series (3 folders and 786 MB, 1875-1971 and 2009-2010) contains copies of photographs, maps, diagrams, correspondence, and other documents gathered in researching the history of the light station, its inhabitants, and its structures. Much of the material was copied or scanned at the National Archives in Chicago. It includes records from the U.S. Coast Guard and U.S. Lighthouse Service as well as material about or from the lighthouse keepers themselves.

odd.p: (Photographs [scanned, 2012] of island and structures, 1960s. Aerial views, as well as the boathouse, fog signal building, light tower, carpenter shop, assistant keepers' quarters, original lighthouse, and oil house are featured in the images.)

odd.p: (Correspondence from the Engineer Secretary to the Engineer of the 11th Light-House District, log book pages, and other items, 1875-1895.)

did.unittitle: Lighthouse keepers' material, personnel information, photographs, diagrams, and maps

scopecontent.p: The Oral Histories series (8 folders and 496 MB, 1953 and 2009-2011) includes materials documenting oral history interviews with individuals who worked or lived at the South Fox Island Light Station while it was in operation. Interviewees include:

James Alger and Paul Stephan, who both served in the U.S. Coast Guard at Clarlevoix in the mid-1950s and helped transfer people and goods from the mainland to various light stations, including the one on South Fox Island;
Zane Bourisseau, who spent summers on the island as a child with his father, Frank Bourisseau, who was an assistant lightkeeper from 1928-1937;
Robert [Bob] Harris, who served as an engineer at the South Fox Island light station in 1953, and his wife, Rheda ;
Robert June, who served on South Fox Island in 1955 and 1956 as part of the U.S. Coast Guard, and his wife, Betty;
David Markle, who served on South Fox Island as part of the U.S. Coast Guard for one season, in 1957, and his wife Audrey.

The interviews serve to document the features of the island and its structures as well as stories of life on the island in the early to mid-twentieth century. The level of documentation varies by interview but may include audio files, transcripts, interview notes, summaries, diagrams, photographs, and copies of related correspondence.

odd.p: ('Agreement on use' form for oral histories given to participants by the Fox Island Lighthouse Association, 2011.)

did.unittitle: Alger, James: interviewed by John Wells October 26, 2010

odd.p: (James Alger interviewed by John Wells, October 26, 2010: Audio recording and transcript. Alger served in the U.S. Coast Guard from 1952 to 1956. From 1954 to 1956 he was at the Charlevoix Lifeboat Station and transferred people and goods to and from South Fox Island as part of his responsibilities. The interview discusses his work during these years, including recollections of South Fox Island and Allen Cain, the last lightkeeper of the station, and his wife [Anna]. Additional records relating to this oral history interview may be found at the Bentley Historical Libary in paper format.)

did.unittitle: Bourisseau, Zane: interviewed by Carla Woodcock of the Lake County Historical Society August 17, 2011

odd.p: (Zane Bourisseau interviewed by Carla Woodcock of the Lake County Historical Society, August 17, 2011: Audio recording. Zane Bourisseau was the son of Frank Bourisseau, an assistant lightkeeper on South Fox Island from 1928 to 1937. Zane spent his summers on the island from age 6 to 15. The interview describes life on the island, as well as his recollections of the structures on the island and events, such as the assembly of the skeleton light tower transferred from Georgia to South Fox in 1934. Additional records relating to this oral history interview may be found at the Bentley Historical Libary in paper form.)

did.unittitle: Harris, Robert (Bob) and Rheda: interviewed by Jan Beller and Linda Baron April 14, 2010

odd.p: (Robert (Bob) and Rheda Harris interviewed by Jan Beller and Linda Baron, April 14, 2010: Summary of interview, 2010. Robert Harris served as an engineer at the South Fox Island light station in 1953. The summary includes information about the couple's life on the island and their relations with the lightkeeper at the time, Alan [Allen?] Cain, and his wife, Anna. Additional records relating to this oral history interview may be found at the Bentley Historical Libary in paper form.)

did.unittitle: June, Betty interviewed by Karen Wells January 27, 2011

odd.p: (Betty June (wife of Robert June) interviewed by Karen Wells, January 27, 2011: Transcript. Betty June lived on South Fox Island in 1955 with her husband, Robert June, who was in the U.S. Coast Guard, and their three children. The interview describes her life on the island, including gardening, canning, housekeeping, and recreation.)

did.unittitle: June, Robert interviewed by John Wells January 27, 2011

odd.p: (Robert June interviewed by John Wells, January 27, 2011: Audio recording and transcript. Robert June served on South Fox Island in 1955 and 1956 as part of the U.S. Coast Guard. The interview describes his life and work on the island, including living arrangements, activities, and the accident that led to his being evacuated from the island to the Charlevoix hospital. Additional records relating to this oral history interview may be found at the Bentley Historical Libary in paper form.)

(David Edward Markle, interviewed August 16, 2009: Transcript. Markle served on South Fox Island as part of the U.S. Coast Guard for one season, in 1957. Interview discusses his life and work on the island, as well as recollections of some of the island structures and grounds. Additional records relating to this oral history interview may be found at the Bentley Historical Libary in paper form.)

did.unittitle: Partial transcript of visit to the island with wife (Audrey Markle) circa 2009

odd.p: (David and Audrey Markle interviewed during a visit to the island, 2009. The Markles lived on the island in 1957. The interview took place on South Fox Island and, as excerpted here, focuses on the current and remembered state of various buildings and grounds.)

did.unittitle: Stephan, Paul and James Alger, interviewed by John Wells October 26, 2010

odd.p: (Paul Stephan and James Alger, interviewed by John Wells, October 26, 2010: Audio recording and transcript. Paul Stephan and James Alger both served in the U.S. Coast Guard at Station Charlevoix in the mid-1950s. Their work included transferring people and goods to light stations such as the one on South Fox Island. The interview discusses their work with the Coast Guard and some of the logistics involved with the light stations. Additional records relating to this oral history interview may be found at the Bentley Historical Libary in paper format.)

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series (462 MB, 1980s and 2006-2010) contains digital images of the island, FILA volunteers, and their work. Most of the images are digital photographs, but some maps are also included. The series is organized into 4 parts by the subject of the images: General, Island structures and grounds, Volunteers, and Miscellaneous. General includes sets of images documenting the island overall, such as web cam images and aerial photographs. Island structures and grounds documents the various buildings and other structures on the island, particularly before and after a restoration or repair project. Volunteers includes digital photographs of FILA volunteers on the island or the water, often working on various projects. Miscellaneous consists of digital photographs of a red dinghy and a boat sunk off shore.
